Award.AwardTitle: The Phase I Robert Noyce Scholarship Program at CCNY: Expanding the Teacher Academy Program for STEM Education in Urban Schools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Robert Noyce Teacher Academy Scholars Program at The City College of New York (CCNY Noyce TA Scholars Program) in partnership with the New York City Department of Education is preparing forty-two (42) talented individuals pursuing undergraduate degrees in science, mathematics, and/or engineering for careers as certified secondary teachers (7-12) in urban schools. This project builds upon the Teacher Academy at The City College of New York. Program elements include: Pre-Scholars Intern Program for sophomores, Undergraduate Noyce Teacher Academy Scholars for junior and senior STEM majors, Summer Internship Program for Noyce Scholars, Support for Noyce Early Career Teachers Program, and a Noyce Alumni component. Sophomore students are invited to participate as Pre-Scholars in an urban internship as a mechanism for identifying highly talented STEM students and recruiting them to teaching. STEM majors from the City College campus as well as the Community Colleges in the CUNY system are recruited and prepared for teaching through a successful and recognized program that emphasizes teaching in urban high-needs schools via clinical immersion in schools. In addition to field experiences in schools during the academic year, these Noyce scholars participate in a summer internship program where they work in summer STEM camps for secondary school children and participate in existing education research projects at CCNY or within the broader CUNY system. Finally, Scholars are supported in their early career (up to two years of teaching) as practicing professionals in the urban high-needs district through professional development and a support network which establishes professional learning communities among Noyce scholars and their mentors. The program targets multiple populations in recruiting candidates with a focus on a diversity of Noyce Scholars who return to their home communities in the city as excellent teachers and role models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Robert NOYCE Teacher Academy Scholars Program at The City College of New York (CCNY NOYCE TA Scholars Program) is a Teacher Scholarship Track, Phase 1 proposal. The program aims to attract highly qualified students from a range of STEM disciplines to teach science and mathematics in secondary schools (grades 7-12). The main goals of the program were:

  • To attract talented students from a range of STEM disciplines to be CCNY NOYCE TA Scholars and prepare them to teach science and mathematics in urban secondary schools
  • To prepare 14 STEM teachers each year over the program (total of 42 teachers)
  • To invite about 14 students per year to join a semester-long internship as “pre-scholars” as a way to attract them into education
  • To prepare the Scholars for the challenges involved in teaching STEM disciplines in the urban high-need district of New York City.
  • To provide support for the Scholars in their early career (up to two years of teaching) as practicing professionals in this urban high-need district through professional development and a support network.

Indeed, as of July 2018, 33 NOYCE fellows had graduated from CCNY and 10 others were en route to completing their degrees in the next academic year.  With respect to the goal of preparing our fellows for the challenges involved in teaching STEM disciplines in urban schools our graduates are currently either teaching or attending graduate school. This is an affirmation of our fellows' commitment to public urban education. 

All fellows report minority status and represent several ethnicities closely resembling the diverse fabric of the urban community in which we are located. Several of them report being the first in their families to attend college or being close to graduating from a four-year college. It was one of the goals of the project that we train STEM teachers that return to their communities and serve as role models for younger students. We are confident that this goal is being achieved.

 Overall, the project has achieved its main goals to attract, train and retain STEM teachers among undergraduate students. Our fellows report that the NOYCE fellowship has added tremendous knowledge and helped them better understand teaching. They claim that the fellowship activities have better prepared them for certification, and, most importantly for the profession of a STEM teacher. Our graduates attest to the impact that the program had on them as persons and as professionals. The NOYCE fellowship has opened doors for them and has helped them develop a deeper and more mature understanding of the teaching profession. They further suggest that the fellowship experience has helped them understand how they can have an impact on other students' lives.
